byline.original: By VINDU GOEL, QUENTIN HARDY and MARK SCOTT
byline.contributor: Vindu Goel and Quentin Hardy reported from San Francisco and Mark Scott from London.

lead_paragraph: American technology companies are no strangers to antitrust challenges by European regulators, but the cost has tended to be measured in money and time, not business practices.

headline.print_headline: Decades of Scrutiny, but Tech Giants Play On
headline.main: Google Joins Its U.S. Peers Under Europe’s Scrutiny

snippet: American technology companies are no strangers to antitrust challenges by European regulators, but the cost has tended to be measured in money and time, not business practices.
abstract: Formal antitrust charges filed against Google by European Commission are latest regulatory challenge to an American tech company by European authorities, which have long challenged titans of field; while tech companies tend to continue doing business as usual while battling regulators, cost to companies is time and money spent defending practices that they should abandon in order to respond to changing technology market.
